Like Bing Crosby and Frank Sinatra before him, Elvis Presley became the newest heartthrob at the microphone.  This time, however, the teen idol brought a new form of music to the mainstream - rock and roll.
By the early 1960s this new form of music had started to get watered down.  The rawness and rough edges were gone, and rock and roll seemed destined for blandness.
A second era in rock music began with the arrival of the Fab Four.  The Beatles would breathe new life into rock  roll and become the most successful and influential band of all time.
By the late 1960s, rock music started to get adventurous.  Even the Monkees were releasing psychedelic music, and The Beatles made the LP into an art form with Revolver and Sgt. Pepper.

In the early 1970s, there was a reaction against the over-the-top excesses of psychedelic music.  The singer-songwriter movement was psychedelic musics polar opposite, and often nothing more than a musician and his or her acoustic guitar.

In the early 1970s, bands like Led Zeppelin and Grand Funk Railroad initiated a form of rock devised specifically for large concert venues.  By mid-decade, stadium or arena rock was in full swing, and bands with big sounds like Boston and Queen dominated the music scene until the 1980s.

Punk rock was largely a reaction against stadium filling bands like Pink Floyd and other so-called pretentious rock acts.  Punk songs were short and raw, and would never dream of containing long guitar solos or complex themed albums like their arena rock enemies.

Punk rock was, by its very nature, destined to self-destruct.  Many punk bands like Blondie began to morph into a friendlier brand of music called New Wave. This shift coincided with a new television channel called MTV that suited their aristic style perfectly.

Heavy metal had its origins with Black Sabbath back in 1970, but it was this bands 1980 heavy metal masterpiece, British Steel, that sent metal on its path to world domination.  By the latter half of the 1980s, bands like Ratt, Def Leppard, and Motley Crue would emerge that were perfectly suited for the excesses that characterized the 80s.

By the 1990s, heavy metal was almost unrecognizable from its ancestors.  There simply wasnt much metal left in bands like Poison, Warrant, White Lion and Winger.  So, the time was absolutely right for a new brand of music called grunge to cut through the artificial fluff in much the same way as The Beatles did in 1963 (see questions 2 and 3).  Instead of Liverpool, however, this time the bands would predominantly eminate from which city?

The 2000s so far (2008) find rock music in a definite downward slope.  Hip Hop and RB dominate the charts, and rock music seems to be unable to produce any bands that can create much of an impact.   Most rock bands are either a hybrid (like rap-metal or pop-punk) or a revival of something old (like garage rock).

Fugue was perfected by Bach. The greatest example is in Toccata and Fugue. It was elaborated in this historical period.
During this period composers began to seek beauty through simplicity in music with only one music line.  Mozart and Beethoven created their masterpieces.

Program music evolved during this period. This was music designed to describe special feelings, objects or even people. Tchaikovsky gave us the best example of program music - his Swan Lake is a story, danced on stage.

It was typical for the music of this period to create atmosphere or a mood, describing nothing definite.  LÃ®sle Joyeuse (The Island of Joy) by Claude Debussy is a typical example of that, due to  the lack of characteristic themes.
This music composition technique is characterized by recurring series of ordered elements which are manipulated to give a piece unity. Arnold Schoenberg made extensive use of this technique.
The music of this modern period combines some features from classical music with trends from the 20th century. Shostakovich appears to be among the most famous composers of the period.
This music became popular in the mid 1900s. It was characterized by the use of very little musical material and repetition of patterns.
During this period, Church was the major patron of music. That is why a great number of composers were associated with it. Just like composer Hildegard von Bingen, who was an abbess of a convent.
During this period the Italian madrigal and the French chanson were created as new types of music. Instrumental music became widely popular. Claudio Monteverdi was the leading composer of this time.

The musical elements used during this period were well defined and clear. The music uses fragments from other cultures or from European ethnic groups. Bela Bartok is one of the composers associated with this period.

This great jazz trombonist and vibraphonist was playing with prominent groups by the mid-1930s, when he was just hitting his twenties. From 1947-1951 he played with Duke Ellington and his wah-wah trombone work was featured in The  Liberian Suite. He is famous for writing Sultry Serenade, now a jazz standard.

This Texas-born musician, who was a jazz professional since he was 10, is generally considered the most innovative trombonist of the Pre-Bebop era. He is best known for his duets with Louis Armstrong and for interjecting the blues sound into almost every piece he played.
This Indiana-born virtuoso, widely regarded as the most important trombonist of all time, is most famous for his compositions Wee Dot, Lament,  and Enigma. His career spanned 1942-1996.

This great trombonist, who spent his best years with Duke Ellington, is famous for developing the ya -ya technique. He was one of the first users of the plunger to create the wah-wah sound used by Ellington to get the jungle band sound he wanted.
Unlike many other jazz greats, this Louisiana-born trombonist spent many years in the house bands in the Las Vegas casinos. He recorded on more than 70 albums until his own album appeared in 1985.

This Detroit-born musician started out as a guitarist and switched to the trombone at 14. After WWII he played with many of the top bands and musicians. He was closely associated  with the group SuperSax. In 1978 he committed suicide in Los Angeles. The International Trombone Association has an award named for him.

This jazz great is a second generation  trombonist. His career really took off in the 1960s. Most people know him for his work in the Merv Griffin Show orchestra and with the group Ten Wheel Drive. Jazz aficionados know him for his rendition of Sam Nesticos arrangement of  A Time To Love.
This Grammy Award-winning musician is one of the few left-handed trombonists. He became Llod Prices musical director after playing with many of the top groups. He appeared on The Cosby Show.
This trombonist and band leader, whose orchestra was very influential in the pre-WWII era, was killed in WWII by friendly fire.

This Pennsylvania-born trombonist played with some of the finest bands starting at age 16. In 1934 he and his brother formed their own band. Although they were successful, they separated in 1935 and formed separate bands. His biggest hits were Marie and Opus One.
